clinical_study.brief_title: Optimal Management of Pain in Hospitalized Patients - Opioid Tolerant Populations.
clinical_study.official_title: Pain Management Options for Opioid Tolerant Patients: a Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Pain is a symptom that drives hospital admissions, and pain management is required by most patients during their hospital stay. Further, the use of medications such as opioids can lead to upward-spiraling doses, especially among chronic pain patients whose resource utilization rates are high. Many initiatives aim to reduce the costs of these "high-resource utilizing" patients. One exciting aspect of improving the management of pain is that this may help prevent patients from ever becoming high-cost in the first place. The purpose of this study is to examine the impacts of an early intervention pathway, in comparison to the current standard of care, for the treatment of pain in opioid tolerant patients. It is hypothesized that patients randomized to the early intervention pathway, in comparison to the control, will lead to decreased costs of care, a reduction in opioid usage within 3 and 6 months, and decrease in hospital readmission rates.

arm_group.description: Those randomized into the control group will receive the current standard of care for pain management. This standard care pathway involves a pain management team consultation only at the request of the primary admitting team. The pain management consultation can occur at any time during the patient's inpatient stay and ends at discharge.

Subjects randomized into the treatment (early intervention) group will receive the New Clinical Pathway: automatic pain management team consultation on the day of admission of their inpatient stay, continued following through discharge, and 90-day support post-discharge.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult patients (18 years and older)
- Known opioid tolerant (as determined per FDA criteria)
- Agree to sign the informed consent and HIPAA forms
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients under the age of 18 years
- No known opioid tolerance
- Do not agree to sign the informed consent and HIPAA forms
